thread.title: Prep football: Storm wreck Apollo’s homecoming, 30-6
thread.title_full: Prep football: Storm wreck Apollo’s homecoming, 30-6

title: Prep football: Storm wreck Apollo’s homecoming, 30-6
text:
Prep football: Storm wreck Apollo’s homecoming, 30-6 Sauk Rapids takes advantage of 6 turnovers and runs for 402 yards to dominate Eagles Post to Facebook Prep football: Storm wreck Apollo’s homecoming, 30-6 Sauk Rapids takes advantage of 6 turnovers and runs for 402 yards to dominate Eagles Check out this story on sctimes.com: http://www.sctimes.com/story/sports/high-school/2015/10/02/prep-football-storm-wreck-apollos-homecoming/73265220/ Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Prep football: Storm wreck Apollo’s homecoming, 30-6 Tom Elliott , telliott@stcloudtimes.com 10:59 p.m. CDT October 2, 2015 Several Sauk Rapids defenders team up to tackle Joey Atkinson of St. Cloud Apollo during the first half of Friday's game at Apollo High School. (Photo: Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com) 
It was a moniker suggested by Drew Anderson that might just stick — homecoming wreckers. 
“We’re pretty unpredictable,” said Anderson, a senior running back/defensive end for the Sauk Rapids football team. “We call ourselves the homecoming wreckers, actually.” 
As Anderson sees it, Sauk Rapids ruined their third homecoming of the season Friday night at Michie Field, beating host St. Cloud Apollo 30-6. 
On Sept. 18, they ruined St. Cloud Tech’s homecoming, too, 30-29. And the Storm wrecked their own last week in a 49-0 loss to Sartell. 
Story continues below. Buy Photo Matt Johnson of Sauk Rapids runs near the sidelines during the first half of Friday's game at Apollo High School in St. Cloud. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudti Fullscreen Buy Photo Several Sauk Rapids defenders team up to tackle Joey Atkinson of Apollo during the first half of Friday's game at Apollo High School in St. Cloud. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Fullscreen Buy Photo Matt Johnson carries the ball for Sauk Rapids during the first half of Friday's game at Apollo High School in St. Cloud. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Fullscreen Buy Photo Tommy Wittowski of Sauk Rapids tackles Apollo's James Blommel during the first half of Friday's game at Apollo High School in St. Cloud. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Fullscreen Buy Photo Ethan Novacinski rushes for Apollo during the first half of Friday's game at Apollo High School in St. Cloud. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Apollo fans cheer during the start of Friday's game at Apollo High School. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Clayton Hoeper rushes for Apollo during Friday's game at Apollo High School. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Fans stand near banners for players Friday at Apollo High School. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Fullscreen Buy Photo Eric Burski of Sauk Rapids tries to track down a loose ball during Friday's game at Apollo High School. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Sauk Rapids fans cheer for their team during Friday's game at Apollo High School. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Ethan Novacinski rushes for Apollo during Friday's game at Apollo High School. Dave Schwarz, dschwarz@stcloudtimes.com Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 
It was a different story Friday. 
“It was a fun game,” Anderson said. “I think our O-line did most of the work tonight.” 
Sauk Rapids (3-4) churned for a season-best 402 yards and four touchdowns on 48 carries. But any statistical analysis of this one should start and pretty much end with this: Apollo (1-6) had six turnovers, including four fumbles. 
“Defense was definitely turnovers and offense, we had a lot of guys step up,” Sauk Rapids senior fullback/linebacker Eric Burski said. “We had a lot of guys out. 
“A lot of guys played 100 percent and did their jobs. Our line blocked real well and our running backs played real hard.” 
The list of key players out for Sauk Rapids right now is as long as the menu at Jimmy’s Pour House. Richard Carriveau is the latest, suffering a neck injury that prevented the two-way player from playing Friday. 
“We had a lot of new guys on ‘D’ this week,” senior quarterback/defensive back Matt Johnson said. “And they’re all young guys, too. 
“They really stepped up. It was really big for us.” 
Johnson, Anderson, sophomore linebacker Tommy Wittowski and junior cornerback Daunte Keller had fumble recoveries. 
Johnson and junior defensive back Ethan Bengtson had interceptions. 
“Our defense did a great job tonight,” Anderson said. “Overall, it was great team play.” 
After a scoreless first quarter, Sauk Rapids scored twice in the second to take a 14-0 lead, getting a 2-yard TD run by Johnson with 9:11 to go until halftime. It culminated a six-play, 92-yard drive set up by Nathan Waldorf’s 57-yard run. 
Wittowski, making his first start, then grabbed a pitch by Apollo quarterback Joey Atkinson intended for Clayton Hoeper with 4:22 to go until halftime. The Storm then went 71 yards on 10 plays, scoring on Burski’s four-yard TD run with 35.2 seconds to go. 
“We were pretty proud of ourselves for the first five games even though our record was 2-3,” Sauk Rapids head coach Bill Magnuson said. “We played some good teams. 
“And then last week, we got our butts handed to us. It was a gut check time for our kids this week. We challenged them to have no regrets; just go right at ’em and play hard. Our kids I thought rose to the occasion very well.” 
Sauk Rapids made it 22-0 with 54 seconds remaining in the third quarter. Koby Thelen scampered into the end zone from 43 yards away. It came right after an Anderson 30-yard run. 
Shortly after that, the Storm made it 30-0 when Anderson scored on a 55-yard run. It was the first time Sauk Rapids had beaten Apollo since 2011, a 31-21 Storm victory, also at Michie Field. 
“After the game, I told our kids that we can’t turn the ball over six times and not tackle,” Apollo head coach Justin Skaalerud said. “It doesn’t matter what level you’re talking about. 
“It was the story of the night.” 
First quarter
